reviewText:
I've played a few visual novels. Most of them have either the ability to make different choices or an exceptional story. This game however has neither. Granted this game gives you a couple boob and semi-nude shots, which is exactly what you would think you'd be getting from the screenshots. If you want to watch some pics of half naked women you'd find more enjoyment in a hentai or some random anime. It's 2014 stuff like that is easily accessible for less with some patience and a decent internet connection. Or if you want to play an actual game there's plenty of nudity in something like The Witcher. And that game leaves nothing to the imagination.

Anyways, cheap nudity and soft cornpron aside there's very little substance to this VN. And I say that because there's barely any character development. It's a short piece of what is to be a series. Although in the three or so hours playing it I didn't feel any vested interest in the characters. I didn't even care about who our main character was going to choose in terms of a lover. The Tenchi Muyo formula is nice. It's one of my favorite anime series but this story felt like a hollow shell of it. And despite it being a series if the first chapter doesn't grab you you're not going to want to read the next one.

If you're looking for semi decent VNs on Steam consider one of Winter Wolves or a Hanako title. This title, unless you're starved for overpriced fanservice you should probably pass on it.

If you don't own this game I think you'd be wise to just purchase this product, this company has really set the standard for PC gaming since this release and you can see it influence the develpoment of popular titles such as Crysis 3, Battlefield 4, Max Payne 3, Diablo 3, Bioshock: Infinite and much, much more.

All in all this is a very satisfying MOBA, I'd stop playing The WarZ in a heartbeat to make the switch to this.

reviewText:
This game is a visual novel, that is eading only/, no voices of any kind are present. There is *spoilers* only 1 choice to be made, and the story doesn't branch too differently whether you choose one or the other.

The art is pretty good, but the story is super standard, there is no meaningul drama and characters aren't very fleshed out, it's also not the best writing out there, without taking into account the typos here and there. Pretty much like many Type B anime series out there at the moment. But if that is your thing however, then this is for you. The novel is pretty short and all of the 'content' worth paying for is already leaked out in the Community Hub for this game, so take a look at that before wasting money on this.

To be honest there are much better visual novels on Steam already. Like Narcissu, and that one is free. Go ahead and play that.

That said, support all kinds of Visual Novels on Steam, for great justice.

Sakura Spirit is a wonderful story about one guy and some special" girls. The situations are very funny and sometimes so absurd that you can't not laugh. But and that is the point you have to know
date: its like you read a book or a manga or something else. A visual novel isn't a "real" game where you can interact with your environment. You get some beautiful wallpapers from those girls that show you the current situation. But that's all. You have only one decision in the whole game and the story ends always equal! So i only recommend it if you like to read

reviewText:
Only one decision point in the entire game, which has absolutely no impact on the plot.

The plot would be serviceable if it actually allowed you to make some decisions, went *somewhere*, and had some sort of closure.
But it doesn't - it sets up a choice between the harem of female characters, but at no point do you get to choose one - the only choice involving how two of the four female leads are dressed in the penultimate scenes.

There's so little plot that you'll have run through the whole thing in two hours tops, including time spent making cups of tea and eating biscuits...

There's no real conclusion to events, no build up of tension, it really doesn't go anywhere.  This would be forgiveable if the CG involved some actual nudity; but there is no REAL nudity whatsoever, it's all implied.  Ditto for the complete lack of sex or the like.

The game struggles at basic romance, and the plot doesn't even give you a conclusion to the relationships it tries to show you.

So:
Effectively no interactivity;
No real nudity;
No sex or physical intimacy;
No conclusion to the plot;
And the plot itself is incredibly thin / brief.

The characters are well drawn and while they're pretty stereotypical they're appealing fun enough for there to have been a shot at a good visual novel here; but unfortunately that opportunity is wasted by a terrible lack of content.

Not worth buying - just watch a vid of a playthrough on YouTube or check out the CGs, there's really nothing more to this game.

reviewText: It all started 2 days ago. I was in my room putting up my poster of Asuna after it finally arrived in the mail from glorious Nippon (Real japanese like me call it nippon just so you westerners know.) I was talking to my friend Nick about how the quality of western games just couldn't match those made by true japanese game masters. I cried myself to sleep that night, drying my tears in the ample bosom of my Asuka body pillow (She's my waifu which is why I don't have a girlfriend.) The next morning I woke up and put on my leaf village headband and kawaii (Cute) pikachu backpack and headed to school. The ignorant westerners there make fun of me for loving superior japanese culture but they dont understand true culture. After school I headed to anime class where we discussed our favourite things about Nippon (I'm the most popular boy in anime club.) After going home I opened up my Steamu (Steam) Library and got ready to play some gamesu (Games) when I noticed that I had recieved a gift from Nick-Kun. It was this game, Sakura Spirit. I was excited to finally play a game not made by the baka gaijin (Idiot foreigner) game devs. (I'm white but Im Trans-Japanese and have carried a katana since I was 7). I opened the game and was immediately in love with the accurate representation of Nippon culture. I have always lamented living in Canada and not being able to go into the forest and find fox and slime girls but in this game I can live my dreams before I move to Nippon (I am going to win a katana/pokemon cards competition to earn the money to move.) Thank you Sakura Spirit for bringing some Nippon to me! Allah!

reviewText:
Sakura Spirit is a relatively short visual novel developed by winged cloud and once published by Sekai project but now by themself. But I do not recommend this visual novel reason can be found below.

The StoryTake on the role of a Rising Judo Star Gushiken Takahiro was two weeks away from the match that would make or break his career -- a championship match where the winner is then signed up to be a young national athlete for Japan.

He's prepared and ready, but that doesn’t stop him from being nervous about his upcoming battle. At the suggestion of his friends and classmates, he goes to a shrine that is rumoured to grant any wish or prayer. He pours all the coins from his already full coin bank into the offering box and says his prayer. After praying, he becomes dizzy and nauseous and eventually faints. When he wakes up, he finds himself in an ancient, unfamiliar place.

While searching for a way back to his village, he stumbles upon two girl wielding swords chasing after two… foxgirls.

Music and ArtstyleMusic feels average at best nothing too fancy here, But for the artstlye it is honestly very good as much I hate to say this I enjoyed the overall artstyle of this Visual Novel the CG scenes are good making good use of smooth colors.

Reasons for not recommending this Visual NovelThe story is very generic, when I first read this visual novel I felt bored very bored because its generic and predictable. Some guy got tranported into another world and then gets into some nice situation where everytime he opens a door there will be a half naked girl in it and then he needs to find a way back to his original home and a great miracle happend he got sent back. (sounds familiar? Probably yes because this type of storyline can be found in everywhere)

The artstyle of the sprites for certain chracther I think the chracther name was slime (I think) those 4 chracthers were so lazily made all of them have the same chracther model and the only difference is the eye colour, and the colour of the slime covering their body, other than that all is good.

The fansercvice, while playing through this visual novel you are literally being slapped in the face with boobs every 15 minutes, this just shows that they are using fanservice to cover up their bad and generic story.

To sum upNo i do not recommend getting this game at all unless you are a sakura series fan or just want a story that slaps you in the face with boobs every 10 minutes in a attempt to cover up their bad plot/story.

reviewText: WHERE DID MY LIFE GO WRONG?

reviewText:
Alright, I know what you're thinking. Or probably thinking - I don't judge if you're not thinking what I came into this pretty sure you were thinking.

Anyway.

Here is my delicate render of what I believe is/was in your thoughts, upon seeing this game: 'Wow. Those are some big ♥♥♥♥in' tiddies. Wait a second, this isn't even a game, it's just another fanservicey virtual novel thing.'

And... you'd be pretty correct. Firstly, those are indeed some big ♥♥♥♥in' tiddies. Secondly, this is a visual novel. Which is cool. If virtual novels aren't your thing, then I don't think this is the game for you because you're probably looking for a game that's a game and not a visual novel. Which, again, is cool. But if you happen to be the visual novel type of person, then read on. If not, go try reading a (non-virtual) book! I recommend White Fang by Jack London.

Anyway, if you're the visual novel type of person, then that's great. This game has got a lot of good things going for it, fanservice aside. Even if you don't like fanservice, well, bear with me.

The art is nice. Sometimes I draw things, sometimes I draw things for cash. Although I am far from one who can be considered the 'best' authority on all things visual art-related, I'd like to think this comment carries some weight, as little as that may be. The art style is very cute, obviously very anime. There isn't a ton of variation in terms of body language (to go with the different expressions), but this is the norm with visual novels, iirc.

The characters are ♥♥♥♥ing adorable. Though I guess it's possible they're a little tropey (I'm no expert), I personally like them. The game isn't extremely long, so yeah, there could've been more character development. But I definitely got attached enough to the girls by the end of it, meaning somebody (or several somebodies) did their job right. The character you play in the PoV of is probably the least developed, but I assume this is for the whole 'stepping into his shoes' thing, even if I'm not a male.

And the story. Oh, man. I admit, when I went into this... it was jokingly. It was to be an ironic little playthrough, maybe some card farming as I went. That kinda thing. I didn't expect to like it much more than a shrug and 'it was okay, I guess' thumbs up. Maybe accompanied by a 'meh' noncommital hand wiggle. I honestly started playing/reading with low expectations. Like yeah, I can see the art's good, but that doesn't mean jack ♥♥♥♥ unless the writing's good, or at least good enough. You see people complaining about the simplicity of cartoons these days? Yeah, well it ain't just the visuals that make cartoons good, man. Writing matters, too. Otherwise the haters would be watching silent, uncaptioned animations all day (not that I'm judging anyone who does). But I digress.

I didn't expect this to be spectacular in any way whatsoever. I didn't expect to be wowed. None of that. I've only heard of this game as being good for tiddies, card farming, and jokes. No more than that.

But... then I played through it. I didn't finish the story on my first go. I actually tried reading it out to a Skype call, which was amusing, to say the least. The session I finished the game, I am not lying to you when I say I almost ♥♥♥♥ing cried. Or maybe I actually did cry, I don't remember. Point is, I got real emotional. Probably more than I needed to, if we're gonna be honest here.

I personally wasn't disappointed. So yeah, I'd give it - at the very least - a thumbs up. Minus sarcastic shrug, to boot!

tl;dr: Good visuals, good story, good fanservice ('good' if you actually like fanservice though), 'idk how to close the game pls help' is the best ♥♥♥♥ing review that will EVER exist of this game. Wasn't disappointed. Buy it for yourself if you can afford it.

Also? Fox. Girls. Holy ♥♥♥♥, fox girls, bruh. If that doesn't convince you to at least check this game out, then ♥♥♥♥ if I know what will.

Machiko for life.

With that being said, I think it should be obvious why a lot of people got this game  ^-^

reviewText:
I try to keep a large view of things when thinking about what to say about games when I talk about them to friends or other people. I will attempt to be as unbiased when writing this review. I will warn those of you that are reading this that there might be some spoilers, but seeing how I finished this game in about 2 hours-ish while trying to figure out how some of the characters sounded like when they were speaking, I don't think you'll mind as much. If you speed read I think you might be able to finish this in maybe 20 Minutes - 50 Minutes, depending on how fast you can actually read. I visited their website and it says that it is their first Original English Language Visual Novel that wil be published on Steam. I assume this just means that it is the first OELVN to make it onto Steam. Now onto the review.

Peronsally, I felt that this game could've been more...
There is a lot of potential in this game, especially in games where it should focus mainly on the story, while giving players a choice to choose where the story goes. A visual novel by any other name.
But this was more of a... digital book, instead of a VN. It gave you only a single choice for the duration of the entire game, which honestly disappointed me. Not only because I only had one choice through the entirety of the game, but it had such little impact on the story that the second time I went through it to choose the other option the only thing that changed was who you went with to the festival. Everything else remained the same.

The story was somewhat generic, but I love stories.
However, this story seemed to go at too fast a pace. Things were happening much too quickly and the story advanced way too fast. Situations changed from confused and nervous, to happy and perverted, to sad and somber, and then to happy and perverted again faster than flipping a coin and watching it fall on the table.

In no time at all you've already, somehow, made it through several days, and then somehow you made it through an entire week! Then suddenly you are shoved through a portal that takes you back into the world where Takahiro was originally from. No explanation as to how that portal appeared, but it did. You got shoved through it. Good job.

I'm not saying that there wasn't a lot of scenarios, because there were a fair amount of scenarios. They just felt rushed in hindsight. They came in much too abruptly, and ended far too quickly, and then another scenario comes in just as abruptly as the last one did. There is no breather, no build-up, it's just one thing after another. There could have been more pauses to lengthen the story, some dry spots where the characters could get to know each other better. But they all seemed to get along pretty well in some very perverted situations.

But then the characters! The characters!
One of the key items to any good story is the characters! But they just don't have any... definition. Nothing to define them, nothing to make them stand out, make them more unique. They're just sort of there, with a REALLY quick and sad backstory. But even then most of the characters don't have backgrounds and the game conveniently states that they all don't remember their past. Just... kind of sounds lazy to me... I'm being honest. There's little heart-warming bonding moments between the characters. They just... kind of splash water on each other and show each other their semi-naked bodies. That's all I remember from those Bonding" moments.

The artwork is very nice! Pretty much all I have to say on the artwork.

There were also some spelling and grammatical errors and typos.

So to reiterate
recommended: but I like any kind of story that can take my attention.\n-Scenes go by really fast.\n-Characters are there
hoursPlayed: but they lack definition.\n-Really short game. I got through it in about 2 and a half hours.\n-Lack of choices for a VN

reviewText:
Sakura Spirit is pretty cool, I guess.

Sakura Spirit is a visual or as I like to call them: magical books. The game revolves around a group of people I could probably beat up. You take the role of rising judo star Gushiken Takahiro, a complete clown who not only ♥♥♥♥ blocks himself, but me in the process. While preparing to train in Judo, a martial art that would be really respectable if Turkish oil wrestling didn't exist. One day, Takahiro finds himself in an old temple where he prays for luck in his next big-time Judo tournament, only to find himself transported into Japan's past by a spirit who is unfortunately not my girl friend.

Here he meets a quirky group of girls who are also not my girl friends. What takes place after that is a 3 hour journey that does not end in snoo snoo in any way. I can't really go into much detail without spoiling anything so I'll try to make it easy on both of us. Like the measle shot.

Sakura Spirit is what you call a gateway VN, it's short, easy to swallow, and kind of makes you wish Takahiro was dead. The characters are memorable and easy to look at, and the situations are goofy and I can't help but find myself smiling while sitting in my box behind Target. But at the same time it has those really awkward character traits that Japanese stories like to fall back on.
Like I said before, Takahiro is a complete clown and I would show up at his Judo tournament covered in oil wearing a reversed thong just to show him who's the real boss of this gym.  But the other characters steal the show and make it worth the 3 hour journey.

Machiko and Maeko are the poster girls of the series, fox-spirit sisters who like to seal panties from the human ladies...Dirty.
Miyo and Narumi are two local humans who try to catch the sisters in what I hope to end in playful lesbian encounters. A man can dream, can't he?

Should you read Sakura Spirit? I mean, I guess. It's cheap, you're not going to lose anything other than spare time going through it. If you can stomach Takahiro with his almost unbearable with his own self felating, cooties avoiding, cringe inducing actions, but you can ignore him and pretend that it's someone much cooler in his shoes. Like Randy Savage, or me.

10/11, A group of squids is called a squad.

reviewText: Sakura Spirt is a prime example of a game that collapsed under the weight of its own ambition. In trying so desperately to separate itself from a myriad of other VNs while catering to a pre-selected audience, Sakura Spirt spreads itself all of the place, so much so that everything about it is thin, flimsy, and overall disappointing. The end result, however, is stuff of unintended comic gold.\n\nSakura Spirt has Great art and Even Greater tiddies

reviewText: This is a poor example of the Visual Novel genre, which is unfortunate because the story has so much potential. The story seems to revolve around the fanservice, rather than the other way around. Where some fanservice is expected from this type of game, the story goes out of its own way to work fanservice into practically every scene. If that were the worst of the story's problems, it could perhaps be forgiveable, but there are several additional problems that turn this story from so-so to bad.\n\nThere are consistency problems within the story. At one point, I thought the program had bugged and skipped me through a part of the story, due to failure on the story's part to remain consistent within itself. There are several ways this could have been done better, but the story as it is leaves you going Now wait a minute
date: I thought..." every so often.\n\nThe story does not branch. This is perhaps the most egregrious problem with the story as it stands. The visual novel presents you with exactly one choice throughout the story. In addition
recommended: the choice has no bearing on anything
hoursPlayed: only giving you the option of seeing one of two events before the two paths merge once again. There is one ending and no branching story
voteText: and you're basically taken on a ride on rails.\n\nI will withhold judgement on the numerous grammatical errors for now
helpfulPercent: as there is supposedly a patch forthcoming to address this specifically.\n\nThis story had huge amounts of potential. Unfortunately
votesHelpful: it seems that potential will go unrealized; this visual novel has been released as a finished game instead of as an early access
votesTotal: indicating the developers have no desire to flesh the story out further and improve the quality of this game.\n\nI will give this visual novel credit; it has beautifully drawn pictures and good ambient music. With a good story behind it
votesFunny: this game could have been favorably compared to other visual novels such as Katawa Shoujo

reviewText:
tl;dr -> invisible nipples. (    ) (    )

Cons:

-very, very poor writing (cringy at many points); bland, forgettable story

-no voice acting

-lazy art – two of the characters are usually holding weapons, during scenes where they are wearing different outfits the weapons are removed but the hands are still in awkward positions

-I do not believe the amount of content justifies the current price ($10.99 CAD)

-if you care about eroge scenes, there are none – this game is pure fan-service only (invisible nipples)

-very limited pool of scenes

Pros:

-artstyle is very high quality

-music is decent

-fast forward option available, many save slots, quick save/load always available

-lots and lots of fan service (cleavage galore)

Overall, if you can buy this game at a deep discount or in a bundle, then it is may be worth a try if you like fan service in visual novels. Be advised, there are countless other alternatives available if you are looking for a good story (Katawa Shoujo) or actual eroge scenes (Katawa Shoujo, Bible Black).

Recommend!

Cheers,
DJSF @DJSF's Rogue Reviews

reviewText:
Note: The rating of this review does not reflect upon the written notes below. Please read them to get a better understanding.
Introduction
After taking on the free Katawa Shoujo (KS) which was considered to be one of the greatest visual novels ever created and originated by an internet community, I then see the release of Sakura Spirit (SS); another fictionalized, fantasy visual novel, created by Winged Cloud and published by Sekai Project. You play as Takahiro; a disciplined and determined--and yet somewhat awkward--individual Judo student who is training and reaching for the stars to become the champion of a tournament that will ultimately determine his path for the rest of his life. Why? Well, he overhears a legend in a locker room about a shrine that will make one's wish come true if they visit the shrine. He ventures out to this shrine, hoping he will find that the legend is true and make his wish, but what he discovers is unlike anything that he has ever seen before.

Story
The story that was implemented in this visual novel was imaginative for the most part, but unfortunately it is about as linear as a board of wood, or two if both of them led to the same destination. At least there was some character development but it didn't keep me engaged enough and it wasn't in depth like KS. There are at least a few comedy moments that were awkward enough to make me smile, but sadly those moments were easily forgotten afterwards. Plus, just ONE choice in this VN? Really? There is only ONE option that results in spending time with four characters--choice A goes with two to one location, choice B goes with the other two to another location--yet it still does not change the story at all.

Overall, in terms of choices and direction, I can only see people playing the story one time, saving it before that one choices, seeing both paths, and then they are done and won't play it again. So, to me it lacked in the story department.

Graphics
For the most part I cannot complain about the graphics. The backdrops are very well done and they are nice and pretty to look at during certain scenes. The characters also have adorable facial animations depending on their mood. And I can't forget the This game includes nudity and explicit sexual dialog" warning on the Steam Store page. There are instances where certain parts of the female's anatomy are colored and drawn in a way that are supposed to possibly engage and maybe arouse a certain audience
date: maybe for some like me. I found some of the "fan-service" styles and awkward moments that they went with to be a little distracting from the main storyline
recommended: such as a certain scene where a certain character was covered chest to toe in chocolate to impress Takahiro. REALLY? But I digress. Maybe that's because the story was too linear that the developers had to find a way to keep the majority of their audience engaged for the prolonged period of dialog and stills.\n\nOverall
hoursPlayed: despite a few distracting scenes
voteText: most environments like the forest
helpfulPercent: market
votesHelpful:
and temple shrine to list a few were not bad.

Music
Like the graphics I think this is another section where SS actually holds up on its own. While some of the tracks may leave you with an annoying earworm tugging on your eardrum
votesTotal: I found the presentation and ambiance to be quite blissful. There were no annoying tracks that distracted me
votesFunny: and plus they were played appropriately. Vividly
commentsCount: I still can recall the "Temptation" track at this moment
column16: with its smooth saxophonist playing in the background.\n\nOverall
column17:
the music helped make this an acceptable experience.

Originally posted by Danny Sexbang (Steam Train):"Where the F*** is that saxophonist?"
Dialog
While the dialog throughout SS was good and everything was understandable
column18: there were several times where the spelling of a certain word or a word that was supposed to be used in the right context was incorrect. Part of me wanted to jump into the VN itself and fix the spelling mistake or error that appeared but I could not do that unless I had a vast knowledge of programming and it's never too late to learn.\n\nOverall
column19: understandable and good

just the errors bothered me slightly.

Functionality
Well

column22: manual

column24: skip
column25: save
column27:
etc. Everything functions the way that it is supposed to in this.

Final Thoughts
Do I recommend this for those who haven't experienced a visual novel before? No. Go play Katawa Shoujo first.

Unless you're a huge and dedicated fan of the Sakura franchise

reviewText:
I came into Sakura Spirit expecting it to be a shallow dating sim game with attractive, overly busty girls. As part of the visual novel genre, I also expected it to have long stretches of text between gameplay decisions. However, Sakura Spirit falls far under my already low expectations for it: there is very little diversity between the female cast of characters and there isn't much gameplay to be found at all—in fact, there is only one choice to make in the whole entire thing. Sakura Spirit, unfortunately, isn't much of a game at all.

Had Sakura Spirit's plot been less generic, I may have forgiven it its incredibly limited player choices. However, the storyline of Sakura Spirit (a high school judo star that goes to make a wish at a secret shrine in the forest before the biggest competition of his life and is then sucked into an alternate reality where spirits exist) is somewhat overdone and rather boring. I found myself reading through an hour's worth of content and then pressing the skip button to see when I would eventually come to some sort of choice in the narrative, while also enjoying the various pictures of attractive characters in promiscuous positions.

The main character is as underdeveloped as the plot. He is both noble and easily flustered, two traits which should be endearing but are actually sources of irritation in a beta character that has absolutely no game at all when it comes to the ways of women. All of the girls are equally irritating: some will clearly try to seduce the main character and then back off at the last second while others will be innocently talking to the main character and then climb onto his lap—all of which would be perfectly acceptable if these advances ever led to any development in the relationships between characters. Instead these isolated incidents only serve to end in a main character who almost seems to be eternally friendzoned. Altogether, the characters of Sakura Spirit are lacking any compelling qualities

Sakura Spirit does have a couple of redeeming qualities. Some of the humor found in Sakura Spirit can be amusing, at first. The game relies heavily on pop culture references, lowbrow humor, and the overuse of common character tropes, all of which earns minor chuckles at the beginning of the game, but grows somewhat tedious later on. Nevertheless, Sakura Spirit does have the occasional redeeming moment. Unfortunately, those moments aren't frequent enough to earn it my recommendation.

reviewText:
Sakura Spirit is perhaps the worst example of a visual novel.
It starts off nicely, you're Gushiken Takahiro, a rising Judo star who wants to be the best in his country. As his tournament gets closer, he gets nervous and asks friends for advice, they tell him to pray in a shrine in order to get good luck. Takahiro follows their advice, enters the shrine looking to pray and then meets a spirit telling him he must do something to improve himself as a warrior. He's transported into another dimension and it just goes downhill from here, as this nice plot just dies in the process. I like to think the writers got bored and didn't care for whatever they put in the 'story' because it's embarrassing to see someone find this entertaining, let alone tolerable  [Yes, I mean the perverts too.]
Some tags used in the store to describe this game are also wrong:
Nudity: No no, those who gave this tag are either upset parents or prepubescent boys who've never seen cleavage on the internet. May I also add that, like every other reasonable review has stressed, nipples [and genitalia] aren't visible, so you're pretty much just looking at a blank chest. I think it's hilarious the amount of people that use this for self-pleasure, since there is absolutely nothing sexually appealing  about the scenes used to allure the audience. The many moments with the so-called nudity happen randomly and it's more effective than a jumpscare. Moments include you walking into a room, turning on the lights and see a girl naked covered in chocolate, her begging you to get intimate and you refuse, because obviously you're a gentleman for playing this game.
Dating Sim: LOL. You'll be disappointed to hear that your character has nothing to do with the girls and/or foxes. In fact, there is only one choice near the end of the novel and it doesn't affect any relationship you develop with any of them. Honestly, making this game a dating sim would've been the right way to go because of it's suggestive themes, but i guess we all don't get what we want now do we?
Mature: More than half of the people who played this are immature, and it doesn't even take a mature person to know this is horrible.

You can get more entertainment off the community hub which is full of screenshots that speak for the game itself.
Once you buy it, be prepared for the judgmental messages you'll receive from your friends or siblings. The only good thing about it is the cost of the trading cards, if you're lucky enough, you'll get a foil card which is worth more than this crap.
Oh, how i wish Steam gave refunds...

reviewText:
This is a game for nobody.  It isn't interactive enough to be considered a dating sim (literally one decision, and playing that one branch is maybe 20 minutes), it isn't complete enough to be called an interactive book. It doesn't commit to the cheesecake (and beyond) enough for the pervs.  It's not funny enough tie all these shortcomings into something more.  Oh yah, and it's incredibly short, even for the genre.  3 hours in and I finished both paths, looked through teh gallery, and then finally quit.

It reminds me of a low-rent Tenchi Muyo.  Which is too bad, because I like Tenchi.

Don't let some of the reviews fool you, this doesn't go much further art-wise than the preview.  Literally every single piece of art in the game can be found by the front page of Google Image Search, without even clicking through.

Redeeming factors:
What art is there is quite good in the genre of anime cheesecake. Unrealistic, idealized, likely not matching what bones actually do, but definitely fun to look at. (if you do end up getting it, make sure to look at the gallery after beating it.  There are some entertaining outtake pictures, which you won't see in-game)
If this really is a prologue as suggested by the ending, then maybe there's more in this world that will be more fun.

Ultimately, there are better dating sims if you want that, there are better interactive novels, and there's more committed cheesecake.  Sakura Spirit seems to try and straddle all three without truly being any of them.

reviewText: I really liked this game. HOWEVER, this game for its price is asking a bit much. While the artwork, music, and quality of story is good. It's short amount (for an above-average reader like myself) gameplay (1-2 hours) is simply not worth the current 7:49 and would be better to be priced as a 5 dollar game. UNLESS there is more planned to be added onto this story seeing as there was only one moment in the game that you were allowed to make a choice, and the game ended with a cliffhanger about your adventure not being over yet. I wouldn't buy a sequel to this but I would countinue to play it if it were updated into a larger story (Hopefully something with a bit more span such as the medium-large amount of play time in the visual novel Katawa Shoujo).

reviewText:
Sakura Spirit is a linear visual novel filled with fanservice. And it is good.

The only real issue I have with this game is with the writing. The text is filled with grammatical errors and poorly constructed sentences, and this can be considerably distracting.

However, if you want a fun story with cute characters, Sakura Spirit definitely fits the bill, and its artwork is gorgeous with a consistent high quality.

The music isn't outstanding, but it does the job. As I mentioned, the story is linear. That isn't a bad thing — many stories, whether they're printed books, films or TV series are linear. Thus, one shouldn't expect Sakura Spirit to be something it's not trying to be. And yes, the story is short, though to claim that it can be completed in under an hour is definitely an exaggeration.

Sakura Spirit is by no means a masterpiece, but if fanservice is what you're looking for, then it's more than worth the £7 it's priced at.

reviewText: Regarding the big ''negative hype'' going around at the moment. I want to say that Sakura Spirit is actually a pretty good visual novel. The Problem though, is that most western people aren't used to this genre and start hating it for the lack of gameplay. But a visual novel, as the name should actually say for itself, is nothing more than a novel with graphics. You read it and don't play it. So if you're into japanese style VN then you should check Sakura Spirit out since the story is, for a western made VN kind of good. I got it when it was in sale so it dind't seem like the short story was a waste of money. And for all the people who are not into Visual Novels or don't have any experience with them. Just don't buy it and please don't hate a concept you don't like/know.

reviewText:
I personally consider Sakura Spirit one of the more...Well..Thought out 'Ecchi' games on Steam. At least it actually functions properly, and doesn't have an issue with running on ALL OTHER brands of GPUs except the one the developper used when creating it!

The game actually runs smoothly, and despite the story being, of course, shallow and uneventful at times, at least, it's bareable, and makes looking at the well drawn ♥♥♥♥ and asses conveniently censored to keep the shallow minded community on Steam happy, at least tolerable.

I'd say, if you're looking specifically for a game to fap to? This is as good a game as it gets if you're for some reason deciding to look for these games on a 3rd party software whose TOS directly doesn't allow full on sexual games.

The controls are very customizable, allowing you to choose whether the game should progress on its own, and how fast/how many seconds it takes between frames to appear, or for new text to appear. You can also simply have it set to remain on the same page until you click any key. This gives the possibility of maximum storyline immersion, or maximum fap capability, depending on your individual desires.

Regardless, I recommend this game purely due to the type of game it is. It would be unfair to rate this game compared to the rest of the games on Steam, as this is hardly a 'game' and more a story telling session, with lots of blushing boobs and conveniently nude, but not revealing, bodies.

I'd say, for what it is? It's one of, if not the, best Ecchi game on Steam, and if you're deliberately looking for this sort of game(BAKA HENTAI! D: ), then I'd definitely say that this one is the best option for you.

reviewText:
Sakura Spirit is a visual novel that follows the main character's journey into a world that is implied to be his city, but from some time in the past. In this world, he dicovers two fox-spirits and two regular human guards that become his close friends. The story focuses on our main characters bond with these four girls, and wraps up with them preventing some destructive slime-spirits from destroying the village.

Before you buy this, please keep in mind that this is NOT a game. It is a visual novel with only 1 choice for you to make. It is also very short. You can finish the story within 2 hours. This, combined with a few more features, makes me not want to reccomend the game:

THE GOOD-The artstyle is phenominal. All the background look very nicely drawn and are aesthetically pleasing, if slightly generic. All the characters are drawn well, and this is emphasised during the unlockable scenes that you can later view in the gallery. I would have liked to see more of the scenes animated however, as most of them were static images, or simply not shown at all and rather explained through text.

THE BAD-The story is mediocre at best. Despite the fact that it's not easy to create a good story that only lasts for 2 hours, the plot manages to be largely focused toward the wish fulfilment of the player.
-The characters themselves are relatively simple. The four main girls have cutout personalities, including: the Tsundere, the mature one, the childish one, and the tease/flirt. None of the characters get much development, excluding maybe one of the foxgirls who was friends with one of the guards as a child. The main character himself loves judo, and that's as far as his development goes. All other characters are negligible in terms of relevancy and development, including the namesake of the game.
-The music is average. None of the tracks were bad per say, but none of them were memerable. I ended up turning the music quite far down during my playthrough. The only theme i really liked was that of the main menu.
-There is no nudity. AT ALL. Even if you're playing with your hand in your pants, you're going to have to settle for softcore porn at best. If that's not enough for you, I suggest you look elsewhere.
-You cannot ♥♥♥♥ any of the girls
-You cannot ♥♥♥♥ the childhood friend
-You cannot decide which pair of girls you like better in-game
-You will never have two qt3.14 fox girls taking care of you in no clothes and wanting to ♥♥♥♥ you
-None of these girls will ever be real
-Why even live

Overall, I rate this game" 4/10. The only part of this experience that I can say i enjoyed was the art

reviewText: In Sakura Spirit, you play as a psychotic serial rappist as he ventures into his own psychosis and the world he creates by doing copious amounts of hard street drugs. Under said drugs, his perceptions of the women in his liferange from scarily complacent fox girls, to warrior women, and he treats each one like the last: a walking pair of boobs who live soley for him.\n\nThat being said, the game is a successful commentary on juvenile male power and sexual fantasies. The game aludes to a sequel of sorts, which I can only hope sees a resolution to this poor, tourtured soul's crisis, which we can only pray equates to months in jail.

reviewText: The story wasn't great, the mechanics are simply clicking to continue and you make one almost meaningless choice. The game only lasts 20-30 hours and its main selling point is its soft-core artwork.\nBut despite this, Sakura Spirit wasn't a chore but rather a memorable experience. Yes its flawed, and very heavily at that but the witty side comments by the protagonist and the humorous situations he inevitably finds for himself make this one of the more enjoyable anime games on steam.

reviewText:
Before I begin. Sorry for the negative rewiev.

I got Hatoful boyfriend" as a gift awhile ago and really enjoyed it. Not after long Sakura spirit started showing up on featured games as a recomandation. Time after time after time it was there and I thought that maybe i should give these ladies a chance.

However I did not wish to pay that much for the game and waited until it got on sale.
As I sat down to play it I had a few thoughts and began to think.
After more than 2 hours I got to the first choice - whch later turned out to be the only choice in the whole game. and I thought "maybe I will get more influense from here?" How wrong was I there...
After completing the first time I unlocked the skip button to dialog I had read. Thank god.
But it wasn't great after that. Heres a few things to sum it up:

Positive:
* Great soundtrack. I really like it.
* Ok plot.
* Pretty girls.
* Nice clothing for the girls that looks awesome.
* The drawing and pictures looked awesome.
* The skip button.

Negative:
* Only 1 choice in the entire game. And it doesn't even matter!
* "This game includes nudity and explicit sexual dialog." No. Not exactly... The dialog is some times "flirty".
* Taka-whatever (the person you are in the game) is a womanizer at heart. He acts and seems to be under the illusion that he is the most handsome guy on the planet. Maybe even in the universe. I really dislike him and had problems connecting with him.
* The girls are under the same illusion as the character you play.
* The girls even seems itemnized at points.
* Most of the dialog is so annoying I wished I had the skip button when I first played/read through the "game".
* This "game" challenged my intelligence in a very bad way. I was thinking "Seriously??! What?!?" most of the time.
* The plot could have been a little better. However the dialog has a long way to go to be good.
* The price of this "game" should be lower. Around half of it might be worth what you get for the money."

reviewText:
Until now you have probably only experienced conditional love. Conditional love is based upon what you do. Perform well on the job, on the team, or in the relationship, and you are “loved.”

In opening your life to the Spirit of Sakura, you have found total love and acceptance. That may be hard to comprehend if you’ve never felt totally loved and accepted by anyone. But it’s true! Unfortunately, you won’t always feel that Gaben loves you. There will be times when you find yourself doubting not only his love, but also his existence. You’ll feel like giving up. Don’t.

When Gaben gave you a new life, it didn’t come trimmed in lace and smelling of perfume. RNJezus began His earthly Sakura in a smelly, damp stable. He tasted real life, and that will be the flavor of your journey with the Spirit —no magic, just the promise of his presence with you.

Gaben says, “I have loved you with an everlasting love; I have drawn you with loving kindness”.

This game is drawn love for you!

reviewText:
I bought this visual novel because I'm a fan of anime style artwork.  I'd rate it high for artwork, but low for choice making. so call it a qualified recommendation, for the reasons stated below:

There is only one choice for the reader to make in the whole reading, and it doesn't really affect the outcome.

That said, I thought the artwork was quite good, and the story was decent enough, but I would not buy this if you are looking for a game with choices to make. (Heroes Rise: The Prodigy, and Heroes Rise: The Hero project are much better for choice making, but lack artwork).

The story seemed to be the prologue of a much longer story though, given the end credits end with a teaser.  Perhaps I'll give the story another chance if they come out with a Sequel"
recommended: it's the anime style artwork that was the draw for me.\n\nIf you do decide to get this visual novel

reviewText:
I wouldn't really call this a game. There is only one choice near the end of the game that doesn't change the the outcome and effectively only forces you to load an autosave to unlock one more screen. You can blow through Sakura Spirit in about half an hour which is one of the few positives because you wouldn't want to play it any longer than that. I wouldn't call it a visual novel either because of the poor quality writing, and trust me, I've played a lot of trashy eroge. The story reads like a junior highschoolers fanfiction. The protagonist is a socially awkward fedora aficionado who shoots down every attempt of the lovely ladies throwing themselves at his feet him for no comprehensible reason. All whilst justifying his sexual frustration by reassuring himself of how much of a gentleman he is for doing so.

If you're new to the genre and looking to play a dating game I would suggest Katawa Shoujo" or if you must play on Steam check out "Go! Go! Nippon!"

And if you are a clever teenager looking to sneak around parental locks to oggle some anime girl breasts then you can find them on the screenshots page!

Happy fapping!

- Otaku Airman"

reviewText:
If you want video game nudity, look elsewhere.  I seriously doubt you are going to find what you are looking for.  If you are interested in more than that, here is the review.

Sakura Spirit is a Japanese visual novel featuring many ladies and a male protagonist.  The plot is paper thin.  The interaction is minimal, featuring few choices of what story path to take.  The visuals are...  well...  the visuals are of scantly clad women.  The ambient music varies from generic Asian to generic pornoesque, depending on the scene.  No voice overs, only text.

The entire experience for me was about two hours on my first run.  There is some replay value if you desire to unlock all of the different gallery pictures, and read all of the different ways the story plays out.  Overall, it was pleasant, but very mediocre at best.  If you are a big fan of anime, and you really love the 'one dude, many women' genre, give it a shot.  For everybody else, I simply wouldn't bother.

reviewText: Why should you buy this game?  For the amazing story, of course.  The beautiful anime graphics of female characters with outrageous curves are obviously secondary and not the main reason you should buy this.  Yes, by the time you read through all of the thrilling tale of slime, fox, demon, and hunam girls encountered by the loveable and totally-not-schizophrenic protagonist Taco Hero or something like that, what, am I supposed to be paying attention to the story?  Err, wait, yes, I am, so yes, Taco Hero is your everyday judo star, who finds himself transported to another world full of spirits (I think it's safe to say everybody here has had THAT awkward situation) where he is quickly arrested for being in cahoots with two panty thieves.  Who themselves are girls.  Why would they steal panties, you ask?  Well, because they don't have any of their own.  Yes, truly Spielberg should learn something from this gem and the heartwarming tale (or in the case of these fox girls, tail, because I'm not smart enough to make any other pun) the whole family, but especially the pubescant youngsters out there, can enjoy.  69/10.

reviewText:
Throw a bit of Quantum Leap, Tenchi Muyo and a taffy factory together, and this is what you get.

1) This is not a dating sim. There is only one choice to make in the entire story, and that choice only seems to affect the gallery. I still have to do a speed run and choose the other option to be sure. Either way, it has nothing to do with the Tenchi Universe-style problem of all of the girls falling all over him while he avoids relations with them all.

2) Nudity? Puleeze. I've seen more skin at a regular beach. Breasts without nipples does not count as nudity. Honestly, I think the flesh-colored balloons were the only nudity" in the whole thing. Sure

reviewText:
So let me begin by saying that this really isn't much of a game so much as it is a light novel. What Sakura Spirit is, is simply a lot of well drawn images mixed with a lot of text. I have to give the artists credit with their ability to draw, but other than that there isn't much else.

Let's start with the story. It starts off interestingly enough and yes I read all of it. There is one choice in this manga that you can make and it doesn't really have much of an impact, in fact it just shows your a different point of view.  The most you're going to have to do is really read and click. That's it. Each of the characters do have their own quirks and characteristics but it's really hard to translate who the characters are with still images and text so it leaves a lot to the player to make connections to the characters themselves. Overall though, the story itself is mostly just a male fantasy with a bunch of girls continually hitting on you and you really have no option but to take it and really do nothing about it.   It's pretty linear, straightforward and it's not exactly executed well.  The fact that you never really see the male protagonist, who is named and already has a personality really breaks player immersion as well, contributing to the aspect that this isn't a game.

Visuals: Okay now this is where this manga's strong points really are. Every image is well drawn, and really pretty. You can tell the artists had fun drawing the characters in different poses but there isn't enough. My major quirk is that this isn't animated. It's a lot of still frames with a few scenes having the same characeter with the three different progessional still frames to show them in different states. But most of the time its just a single still frame. The art could have been really amazing if they had animated the scenes, granted it would have been A LOT more work, but at the same time it's something that you should be prepared to put in while you're working on a game or if your art in general is going to be the fundamental focus of your game.

Gameplay.

Overall if they made this more actiony, gave the player more freedom in choices and some cool combat, this would actually be a game, and I could see it as being something entertaining. There would be a break in the constant slow pace of reading through paragraphs of dialogue and allow more control for the player that a game should give.

Rating: his game should be rated around pg-13 or a little higher, its nowhere near 18+. It has suggestive dialogue, and while there is some nudity it's all suggestive and covered. You will not see anything. I played this game in my lecture hall because of how tame it was. My suggestion, if you're going to go for it, give it 100% don't bother holding back.

My recommendation: T If you're looking for a really light, linear manga with really pretty images and a lot of suggestive content. Then sure, I can see that you may get some enjoyment from this, otherwise, I can't really recommend this for anyone. For those looking for some form of hentai buy the game, support the devs, but it isn't worth it. There was a lot more that could have been done, and I hope the devs really try and push what they can do with their other work.

reviewText:
Even buying this on sale I feel like I spent too much on this...experience.

The art, for me, was the primary reason for buying this game. I thought it looked nice, so I bought it. Big mistake. While the art for character sprites and event CG's is well done, and it has nice backgrounds, that's about as far as it goes visually since everything else looks like they barely tried and looks bland. Although even then the art has impossible breast-physics and the girls all look fundamentally the same just with different hair, eye colours, and clothes.

The 'story' and characters were...
Well, about ten to twenty minutes into playing, I decided I was thoroughly bored and uncaptivated by the story or the characters and skipped the rest of it just to see the CG art. There was nothing really likeable about anyone besides that they were vaguely cute, and other than that were a cliche mess.
There was also a lot of historical incontinuity and other mistakes with the labels of weapons and such.
There is a single choice in the whole game that affects nothing besides giving you some more CG's of pretty much just the girls breasts and nothing more.

The music wasn't anything special, although I got so sick of one track -I'm not even sure which one it was now- that I ended up muting the game. The rest was just plain unremarkable.

I feel wholly unsatisfied and disappointed that I've played visual novels in languages I can barely understand and be far more captivated and intrigued than this one that's written in my native language. For me personally, nothing salvages this 'game', not even the cute artwork.

reviewText:
So let me begin by saying that this really isn't much of a game so much as it is a light novel. What Sakura Spirit is, is simply a lot of well drawn images mixed with a lot of text. I have to give the artists credit with their ability to draw, but other than that there isn't much else.

Let's start with the story. It starts off interestingly enough and yes I read all of it. There is one choice in this manga that you can make and it doesn't really have much of an impact, in fact it just shows your a different point of view.  The most you're going to have to do is really read and click. That's it. Each of the characters do have their own quirks and characteristics but it's really hard to translate who the characters are with still images and text so it leaves a lot to the player to make connections to the characters themselves. Overall though, the story itself is mostly just a male fantasy with a bunch of girls continually hitting on you and you really have no option but to take it and really do nothing about it.   It's pretty linear, straightforward and it's not exactly executed well.  The fact that you never really see the male protagonist, who is named and already has a personality really breaks player immersion as well, contributing to the aspect that this isn't a game.

Visuals: Okay now this is where this manga's strong points really are. Every image is well drawn, and really pretty. You can tell the artists had fun drawing the characters in different poses but there isn't enough. My major quirk is that this isn't animated. It's a lot of still frames with a few scenes having the same characeter with the three different progessional still frames to show them in different states. But most of the time its just a single still frame. The art could have been really amazing if they had animated the scenes, granted it would have been A LOT more work, but at the same time it's something that you should be prepared to put in while you're working on a game or if your art in general is going to be the fundamental focus of your game.

Gameplay.

Overall if they made this more actiony, gave the player more freedom in choices and some cool combat, this would actually be a game, and I could see it as being something entertaining. There would be a break in the constant slow pace of reading through paragraphs of dialogue and allow more control for the player that a game should give.

Rating: his game should be rated around pg-13 or a little higher, its nowhere near 18+. It has suggestive dialogue, and while there is some nudity it's all suggestive and covered. You will not see anything. I played this game in my lecture hall because of how tame it was. My suggestion, if you're going to go for it, give it 100% don't bother holding back.

My recommendation: T If you're looking for a really light, linear manga with really pretty images and a lot of suggestive content. Then sure, I can see that you may get some enjoyment from this, otherwise, I can't really recommend this for anyone. For those looking for some form of hentai buy the game, support the devs, but it isn't worth it. There was a lot more that could have been done, and I hope the devs really try and push what they can do with their other work.

reviewText:
It's one of the worst visual novels I've ever played (Or read? Whatever). The writing is absolutely abysmal, filled with out of place japanese terms (Kami, imouto, etc.), typos and extremely juvenile content. It barely makes any sense and the characters are all annoying stereotypes.

The presentation is a bit better with some fantastic backgrounds, unfortunately this is technically a nukige without sex or nudity so most of the time they are covered with non-stop fan service that ends up dragging this game down even more. It's a shame since again, it's not an ugly looking game, hell, the UI is extremely clean and there are tons of options but really... do you need over 10 save slots for a 3-4 hour long visual novel with two choices?! The music is pretty average though, not a single track was particularly memorable to me.

Overall, if you want a visual novel with decent writing that's actually fun in a not cringeworthy way on Steam you could check out Christine Love's games, World End Economica, the upcoming Grisaia No Kajitsu and Higurashi or hell, Paca Plus and Hatoful Boyfriend. Or you could go to JAST or MangaGamer and buy Kara No Shoujo, ef: A Fairy Tale Of The Two, Saya No Uta, Aselia The Eternal or a full on hentai game since this game is stuck being softcore porn and it's even more poorly made than most nukiges out there. Avoid this at all costs.

reviewText: as someone who has Read/played many visual novels this is not worth your money. there is no actual nudity there is no explicit sexual dialogue just hints at that sort of them and very pg13 pictures. but that's not why it's a bad visual novel. reviewText:
I bought Sakura Spirit for a little over $3. Thank goodness because I don't reckon it's worth full price. If you can snatch this game for less than $2 then it may be worth it. You buy this game absolutely for its title. Sakura Spirit is very catchy marketing-wise. In comparison a title like Nekopara Vol. 1 isn't (although a better game).

It's not the game that everyone thinks it is (and certainly not what I thought it would be like). The store page says something like it contains nudity and explicit sexual dialog. Maybe that is true for a nine year old playing the game. Anyone below that age just wouldn't understand. So that's just false marketing. No nipples means no nudity in my books.

Gameplay-wise it's just a story. Very long story! Made me so tired, I fainted more times than Maeko-chan. There's very minimal graphics content. Character templates and backgrounds were highly reused throughout the game. Within a 6 hour time frame of playing the game and the many scenes, you will only witness about fifteen special artworks. All of which is neatly packed into a Gallery" option in the main menu. Other than that
date: all characters strike the same pose and wear the same outfits throughout!\n\nIn all honesty I was hoping to see some animation or something that will show the emotions of the characters. Like a character raising an apple with their hands
recommended: whether the character is embarrassed or camera panning of the scenery. Instead you miss out on small fast transitional winks and smiles on character faces because it only happens once after you press spacebar to move onto the next dialogue. Speaking of which
hoursPlayed: there was a lot of unforgiveable grammatical errors in the dialogue.\n\nMusic was really repetitive and started to get annoying. It sounded like 50's classical porn music during every area or situational change. But if the area or the situation was same or similar
voteText:
the music will be repeated.

For me the Steam overlay is very sluggish for some reason in this game. That was also annoying as heck!

This might sound a bit cheesy

reviewText:
I can not in good concious recommend this game because it is not a game. Games require as per their definition the ability to play them, and this piece of software does not meet that definition in the most basic sense. The software consists entirely of one choice towards the end of the story, and in fact has more choices when configuring the preferences than when playing it.

As a review of the software, as I'm now calling it, it had a very nice interface. With transparancy, and a nice clean and consistent look with many sakura flowers. The save feature had multiple image slots for save games to show exactly where each save in the storyline was. It also featured many preferences, however some of them were lacking in ability. The auto story mode could only be configured from impossibly slow to painfully slow leaving you reading the text far faster than the next line appeared. The other features seemed to work as expected text speed, skip feature, and volume controls.

The software featured all of the expected tools for the type of game it attempted to be without any of the gameplay. The art of the software was well done, and enjoyable. The story was great as a sort of satire of the common tropes of this genre, and perhaps the utter lack of gameplay was again a satire on the genre, however, I found it went too far.

Overall you should not buy this game, but if you enjoy these types of games this may be worth a purchase for the laughs.

reviewText:
Let's say I need to start this review by saying that I LOVE visual novels. Katawa Shoujo, Cinders, , Kira Kira, Dear Drops, Hatoful Boyfriend, Quartett and others titles from this genre are something I read and enjoyed most of them as all of them contained really good stories with interesting and likeable characters (Misha hardcore fan from Katawa Shoujo :D) with that important element, which make me come back to them and read them again. They were all special in their own ways.

But unfortunately there are some Visual Novels which lack in many elements, making them unfortunately inferior to other titles of this genre. Unfortunately Sakura Spirit is one of those titles. And trust me, I'm REALLY lenient on how I review Visual Novels, as I have soft spot for them in my heart. But I can't force myself to give positive review for this one.

Normally I would start by saying how plot looks like and what you may expect from the story, but problem is that... story here doesn't really exist. I realize what kind of genre this VN hits into (I LOVE Ecchi, so yeah :D), but you know, I expect something else as a bonus to at least review it in positive way. To summarize it it's about a hero which is promising Kung-Fu fighter which ends up in another world after visiting certain temple to pray for some luck. Later it's just 2 fights, some dialogues which don't really add anything useful to the story and mostly embarrasing situations which are the essence of ecchi stories (yeah, BOOBIES) and... that's it. In this VN there is ONE route and TWO choices where you 'decide' what happens next and those choices make story look really similar to each other. When you compare it to something like Kira Kira which may last even +40 hours or more, this is just depressing. Sorry folks, Visual Novels are about reading story and it's hard to call this a story when it's so short. It should take you max 3 hours if you are really lenient and 1,5-2 hours if you read it at somewhat decent pace. Also I noticed lots of grammatical issues, which let's face it shouldn't really happen in something that is all about reading (and enjoying some views :D). For me at this point this title looks like an incomplete VN with just one route and... zero additional content, in almost hardcore alpha state, which shouldn't be released yet in my opinion.

But I need to say that one thing in this title is good - Art. Girls are sexy, adorable and well, you may enjoy their looks for sure. If you look for eye candy when it goes to art, this one is pretty good choice in this regard. I need to salute and congratulate the artist, as he did one hell of a work. I can't say bad word about it.

To summarize it - it's ecchi title which is just... ecchi. It provides nothing else as story pretty much doesn't exist and it's so short that 10 euro is too high of a price tag for a title with flaws glaring as those. While I love to look at some anime-like ladies and I'm big fan of ecchi, I'm afraid good art alone isn't even close to give this title a serious consideration. Buy it ONLY on serious discount and if you are hardcore ecchi fan. My honest advice.

reviewText:
Based on all the abundance of good reviews and my own wonderful experiences with visual novels on Steam so far, I was really hoping to like this game. But, overall it was a bit of a disappointment. Don't get me wrong, I wasn't expecting some story-rich plot anything spectacular. I can appreciate fluff for what it is. I enjoy guilty pleasure gaming from time to time just for the sheer entertainment value. But, this game was just too lacking in nearly every way for me.

The art is well drawn, and the characters are beautiful--but doesn't have much in terms of actual character design. Most characters have one, or maybe two expressions. If you look at each character side by side, there is barely no distinguishing them aside from the color of the hair and clothes. I know the game celebrates big breasts and shiny butts, and there's nothing wrong with that--but if you're going to make it the focus of your game, why not add a little variety to the body types and facial features?

You can tell there is decent production value, but I really wish they would have used it to the fullest extent. Voice acting would have been a great touch, and might have added a little depth to the characters. More music would have been great too, especially without voices, but there seems to only be two or so songs. Choices would have also been worthwhile, so be warned if you enjoy your visual novels with lots of options and different routes or endings. This game has none, which is a shame considering the whole harem" style of it. There is a single choice given in the entirety of the game
recommended: it doesn't really have an effect on the plot at all. This is more of a kinetic novel
hoursPlayed: which is simply a story played out for you with little or no interaction on your part. Which would have been fine

I don't understand the point of this at all. Do not buy, even if you get it for a buck.

I bought it out of curiosity in the Steam sale because I heard that it was about a judoka and I like martial arts stories. I had assumed it would be some sort of choose your own adventure type of story... but it ended up being a completely linear sequence of typo-laden text with horrible writing, repeated images, and little in the way of discernable plot.

Again, making this clear to anyone who might be poised to buy this: There are no choices. There is little story. There is no dialogue. Spend your money on a good comic book with martial arts themes, like Lone Wolf & Cub"

reviewText:
This game is god tier. Why would you be so ashamed to show your friends your playing this game?
Its top class, 600% better than Call of Duty or Fifa / whatever is mainstream these days. I'd much rather see lewd girls + boobs rather than some group of men jogging around a football pitch on birds eye view.

Before you know it you will be hooked onto the story and have an emotional feel for the characters. Very much like reading manga in a much more colourful way + suitable background music to enlighten the mood.

The specs required for this game is minimal even PCs over a decade plus and play the game meaning everyone can experience this even with £200 modern value desktops /notebooks. If you have a powerful PC like many of us here on Steam do then you can grab your phone / tablet and use the Splashtop app to remotely control your PC and play this game in bed!

reviewText:
It's too short. that is the small version.

I liked the characters and the setting a lot, however since the story was extremely short it just did not get out quite right.
I also found the lack of choices that usually can be found in VN a shame, there is 1(!) choice in the whole game...

the art is pretty all around, from the character designs to the fullarts you get in certain scenes and the backgrounds, all were well done in my opinion. I also liked the background music, never did I find it disrupting and most of the time it was appropriatefor the situation, I did find there wasn't too much different scores...

the dialogue was mostly funny and there were some good moments (not spoiling anything here since... well... it's so short everthing I spoil will be a major spoiler...).

but the This game includes nudity and explicit sexual dialog." warning you get is well~ barely applicable. there were some moments but nothing really too much.

As for the €10
recommended: It's a bit much for the amount of time you get to spend with the VN

reviewText:
I actually liked the game and the story appealed to me, however with that said the game is relatively short with only one alternate choice presented in the entire game which doesn't effect the ending. I would have liked to have seen mulitple choices that would lead to different routes with the romantic interests in the game, each having a unique ending.

I also want to add there's no nudity or explicit sexual dialog in this game contrary to what steam says, there is some revealing scenes with major side boob but that's as much as you get. The sexual dialog is hinted at in jokes or innuendo, but nothing explicit or graphic is discussed in the game's dialog.

If you can get this game for less than 50% off I say give it a try...if for nothing else, the game cards will put around $2.00+ back into your steam wallet if sold on the market. If you enjoy the harem comedy genre of anime/manga, you will enjoy Sakura Spirit...the story is decent and the artwork is high quality.

reviewText: A lot of people seem to buy dating simulations/text-driven stories such as Sakura Spirit in the hope for an actual 'decent amount of gameplay' and enveloping storylines. That's not what you buy it for, this is the next step in the Kawaii Desu Uguuu~ Anime Boobufestu Challenge saga, in which one must overcome the trials of which the game puts them through and be known as the Sakura Spirit Challenge Winner. If you are feeling even braver, you could try your hard at the Go-Go Nippon, My First Trip To Japan Challenge.

reviewText: This game is comedic and entertaining, but quite ecchi all throughout. This is not an RPG, there is only 1 point at which you may select from multiple dialog options, and regardless of what you pick the ending will be that same. This dialog option will effect the next few scenes of the novel, but it will reconnect with the other option's path after a short time. This plot isn't the best quality about this game, its quite generic and predictable. The highlight of this game would be the the high quality artworks. This game has a lot of nudity and partial nudity, so play at your own eyes expense. I reccomend this game only because it is accurately advertised with the videos you find on the store page, I would not recommend actually playing this game unless what you're looking for is a cheaply put together story with high quality perverted images. I personally enjoyed this game because i didn't think the game makers would actually take the sex jokes and perversion as far as they did, so it has no replayability for me since its no longer a surprise, but was interesting in the first playthrough.

reviewText:
I just want to start off by saying that this game is not for everyone. If you don't like anime or dramas, this game probably isn't for you. I had the original game (Non HD) for some time, but only finished one or two senerios. After buying the HD version on steam and investing quite some time into it, I can garuntee that you will love this game.

Pros:
-Absolutely stunning soundtrack
-Well written and flesh out characters. There isn't a single main or side character that has an inconsistency or hole in their story
-Long and touching routes (you will be brought to tears)
-At least one of these senerios is relatable to your everyday life.

Cons:
-The art style. People seem to hate the art style. I think it grows on you as you play, but I didn't care for it originally.
-Length. At times there is a lot of filler text that isn't important to story, and makes routes take so much time. I found myself skipping a lot to get to the important bits.

All in all this game is completely worth the price, as it will open your eyes and immerse you in a world where you can't control your emotions, they control you.

reviewText: This game is comedic and entertaining, but quite ecchi all throughout. This is not an RPG, there is only 1 point at which you may select from multiple dialog options, and regardless of what you pick the ending will be that same. This dialog option will effect the next few scenes of the novel, but it will reconnect with the other option's path after a short time. This plot isn't the best quality about this game, its quite generic and predictable. The highlight of this game would be the the high quality artworks. This game has a lot of nudity and partial nudity, so play at your own eyes expense. I reccomend this game only because it is accurately advertised with the videos you find on the store page, I would not recommend actually playing this game unless what you're looking for is a cheaply put together story with high quality perverted images. I personally enjoyed this game because i didn't think the game makers would actually take the sex jokes and perversion as far as they did, so it has no replayability for me since its no longer a surprise, but was interesting in the first playthrough.

reviewText:
Not even a game actually, only once do you even make a decision or something. Sakura Spirit is a visual novel, an eroge but not hentai. For something like this to be on Steam, its kind of a shock.

Basically, the story is typical anime scenario. Guy gets transported somewhere, ends up getting involved with whatever's going on and also 'bonding' with the females who all happen to be 'abundant' in the chest compartment, even the young one. But surprise, surprise, I actually found the story funny. Cliched at some points, but still enough to make me chuckle here and there. The art looks nice and there's plenty of fanservice.......you might not want to read this when people are around.

But this is Steam, a video game platform. Despite being alright, I only recommend this should it go on a sale. Its quite cheap actually, but you probably wouldn't want to pay full-price just to read something. Otherwise, Sakura Spirit is good, I like it enough.

reviewText:
So, over an hour into this... entertaining piece, I'm forced to acknowledge that it sorely lacks in one thing I'd like to see...

Actual game mechanics.

While I have about twenty years' experience with this, hm, graphical and narrative style and subject matter, it seems that the games I played in the nineties and onward had, y'know, choices to make...

Still, this does have entertainment value, even if it's essentially a digital comic rather than a game.

*Addendum*
I stand corrected. About 1.3 hours into the game, I got to make a decision.
From this point on, it seems I might even have more choices to make. But Ye Gods, that was a long introduction sequence... O.o

reviewText:
From a game standpoint... this is not a game. It's a visual novel. A visual novel that is not so secretly leaning on the visual side of things. I don't want to tell you much about the story, as that's the entire thing. There's only one spot where this resembles a game. This is where you can make a choice. The choice then changes one section of the game before going back into the linear story. You really just click during this game. That's the extent of gameplay. No animations, no movement, not really any choices. It's not a game, but... well it's called a game on here so... that's why I have to make this absolutely clear up front. This is a bad game and is not recommended for playing as a game.

That being said, I'd like to go into my horrible reasons on why I made this a recommendation. I'm a lonely person, I find the girls in this game to be drawn quite attractively, and there's boobs in it. No nudity, just lots of suggestive clothing, positions, and situations. Basically, to be perfectly blunt, it's fap bait. You know that if you're willing to pay ten bucks from what you've seen and heard of this game, you're doing it for that. I certainly wanted it for that very reason. I'm not ashamed of it... even if it is pretty pathetic. All I'm saying here is... if you're looking for a decent time doing your business and you don't want to go off into potentially virus filled sites... or just Google image searches... then this is a fine purchase to make. Just don't be fooled. You're not getting a game or a particularly engaging story... you're getting still images of hot anime girls that have a little personality. That's about it.

Considering the price, the fact that it's not even a game but pretending to be one on here, and the lack of depth, I have to rate it 2/10. If there weren't the girls in it... it'd probably be a 1. (This is the problem with the yes or no on recommendations... I have to make the call on ultimately one or the other and stuff like THIS happens... I'm sorry)
