reviewText:
Sakura Spirit is one of those games I wish I could recommend.

It has pretty high quality art when compared to many visual novels on Steam, and even though the dialogue and situations can be pretty ridiculous, some jokes made me laugh and you can definitely see some love from the developers shine through despite the mistakes...

But sadly, the game has a fatal flaw : you have no control at all over the story. There is only ONE CHOICE IN THE WHOLE GAME, WITH ONLY TWO OPTIONS TO SELECT. And the worst is that this choice" barely matters at all.

The fun of visual novels is to be able to replay the story differently. It works best when you need to play all the "branches  of the story tree" in order to truly figure out what is going on. When the game involve sexy girls and romance
date: being able to romance the one you like is also a major incentive to play a game like this.\n\nBut there is none of that in Sakura Spirit. Just one path in which you interact a bit with all the girls
recommended:
but can't choose one. And I'm not even talking about unlocking romantic/erotic scenes : you can't even decide to spend more time with your favorite girl in order to talk and learn more about her!

It is not a game : it is a digital picture book for teen and adult anime fans.

I guess technically that makes it a "visual novel"
hoursPlayed: but without interaction
voteText: why purchase this rather than watch an anime or comic which will have more pictures and be more dynamic?\nIf I can't play a role in the story
helpfulPercent: I'll just watch a technically more elaborate story with roughly the same subject. And there are legions of those ("Izumo - Takeki Tsurugi no Senki" comes to mind).\n\nThe worst part about Sakura Spirit is that since there is one (meaningless) choice into the game
votesHelpful:
it means that the game engine actually supports a tree-structure narrative...
...And that means that implementing different branches for the different girls and/or more choices would have been quite easy for the developers.

Just 10% more work from them would have made the game 200% more enjoyable.
Even if you didn't give us a branch per girl
votesTotal: at least giving us some conversation options to vary the dialogue would have been a step up...\n\nIt is truly a shame. My hopes is that the developers will use critiques like those and the money they earned in order to remaster the game
votesFunny: by adding choices and girl-specific events. Steam would allow this and it would actually be a great consumer-friendly upgrade and gift for people who have purchased the story.\n\nWill the devs do this gesture of good will? I sure hope they do."

reviewText: A waste of money
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Sakura Spirit is one of those games I wish I could recommend.

It has pretty high quality art when compared to many visual novels on Steam, and even though the dialogue and situations can be pretty ridiculous, some jokes made me laugh and you can definitely see some love from the developers shine through despite the mistakes...

But sadly, the game has a fatal flaw : you have no control at all over the story. There is only ONE CHOICE IN THE WHOLE GAME, WITH ONLY TWO OPTIONS TO SELECT. And the worst is that this choice" barely matters at all.

The fun of visual novels is to be able to replay the story differently. It works best when you need to play all the "branches  of the story tree" in order to truly figure out what is going on. When the game involve sexy girls and romance
date: being able to romance the one you like is also a major incentive to play a game like this.\n\nBut there is none of that in Sakura Spirit. Just one path in which you interact a bit with all the girls
recommended:
but can't choose one. And I'm not even talking about unlocking romantic/erotic scenes : you can't even decide to spend more time with your favorite girl in order to talk and learn more about her!

It is not a game : it is a digital picture book for teen and adult anime fans.

I guess technically that makes it a "visual novel"
hoursPlayed: but without interaction
voteText: why purchase this rather than watch an anime or comic which will have more pictures and be more dynamic?\nIf I can't play a role in the story
helpfulPercent: I'll just watch a technically more elaborate story with roughly the same subject. And there are legions of those ("Izumo - Takeki Tsurugi no Senki" comes to mind).\n\nThe worst part about Sakura Spirit is that since there is one (meaningless) choice into the game
votesHelpful:
it means that the game engine actually supports a tree-structure narrative...
...And that means that implementing different branches for the different girls and/or more choices would have been quite easy for the developers.

Just 10% more work from them would have made the game 200% more enjoyable.
Even if you didn't give us a branch per girl
votesTotal: at least giving us some conversation options to vary the dialogue would have been a step up...\n\nIt is truly a shame. My hopes is that the developers will use critiques like those and the money they earned in order to remaster the game
votesFunny: by adding choices and girl-specific events. Steam would allow this and it would actually be a great consumer-friendly upgrade and gift for people who have purchased the story.\n\nWill the devs do this gesture of good will? I sure hope they do."

reviewText:
Not really sure what to make of this game. I went in expecting more of a full game, but got something more akin to a demo version.

The game drew me in with the artwork and I was hoping for some interesting choices or paths down the storyline. But there's literally only one option and all it changes is what Gallery CG you unlock. The ending it results in is still the same, no matter what choice you make.

It's clear that the devs want to make more out of this, going by the ending card message. Here's to hope that they improve on what they have and add some more meat to the whole game, because right now it's looking pretty slim.

As I said before, the artwork is pretty good. Although the design is very hit or miss on the characters, Tsuyuri standing out the most, not matching any of the others in any way or form. The cast of villains" is just a case of copy/paste with differently coloured hair and eyes.

Storywise it's quite lacking. The background story is way too short and thin
date: you don't know anything about the main character apart from him being a "Rising Judo Star" and see traces of him being a stuttering and silly carbon copy of most bland animé MC's with a little dash of Gary Stu over him. The girl cast is nice
recommended: but you hardly get to know them in the short time that you get to play (aka: read) the game. Just when you get to the point that you start to see some development
hoursPlayed: it ends.\n\nThen there's the writing. Sentences have very stiff structure
voteText: some come out almost as if they were translated literally from Japanese even though the game is English from the start. Some sentences have several spelling errors and grammar issues. The main writer also seems to have a fetish for the word "seemingly". So the game could do with some serious quality checking
helpfulPercent: including a couple of editors and proof readers before getting released.\n\nSo in short
votesHelpful: would I recommend this game for VN / Eroge fans? Not really. You'll get some light fanservice
votesTotal: nothing overly lewd. The writing is subpar and the ending way too quick with nothing really major in terms of choices. I have to give it to the devs for the art though
votesFunny: for being their first (?) game it is quite well done. But other than that this doesn't really go to any great lenghts to improve on the genre."

reviewText:
For a first original work of a company that already licensed some other Visual Novels, Sakura Spirit had an interesting setting, and nice visual, the problem with it was the abrupt ending.

The duration is around 4 hours (played half in offline mode, so it doesn't add to the full count), and while it does a proper job developing the main heroines, it lacks on the rest, the story could have been more explored, such as the characters from the present, and the main character was obsessed with his tournament, all the time he only cared about returning to the present just for that, nothing else was important or did he ever mentioned it.

Though, the epilogue was nice, and the ost used did a proper job on making the japanese ambient.

From a scale of 1 to 10, I would give it 5/6.

reviewText:
This is a case of 'you get what you paid for' if you wanted a Visual Novel. Voiceless, generic japanese style music and with its graphics meant to obviously attract the male (teenager aged) audience, I was rather bored with it within minutes of playing.

This is not to say that this is a bad visual novel, as I'm likely spoiled by visual novels that had actual (usually complicated) plot, multiple paths and endings, so take this review from a 30-ish year old man with a grain of salt. While bland for me, it's several steps above my tolerance levels compared to the official Baldur's Gate novel.

...Before anyone complains, I said the official NOVEL of it, not the game. There's a difference, look it up.

Anyways, As far as I can tell, this is likely the developers first game ever from my searches on the internet, so it can somewhat explain why the game is bland to me. Could the developer improve? Only if he or she is willing to be, so I can only hope so.

reviewText:
Sakura Spirit is a linear Visual Novel. This means their are really no choices to be made that effect the outcome or change the events* , you are here to read the story and enjoy the artwork.
*(Technically there is one choice that effects which group of girls you spend time with at the festival near the end of the game but it has no impact on the actual story and the game can be saved before making this choice and you can quickly replay the different scenes before it carries on as normal)


The story involves a young rising Judo star, nervous about a big match coming up, who whilst praying at a supposedly magical shrine to calm his nerves is whisked away to another world. Here he meets two female fox spirits who are at odds with a nearby village and the young female warriors of said village. The young man must help both groups come to understand one another whilst finding a way back home and preventing the village from being attacked by other spirits.

When it comes down to it the story is tired and predictable, however the writing and descriptions are very good, and these almost make up for the lacklustre plot. Likewise each of the female characters are pretty much your standard animé stereotypes and although there are a few flashes of deeper character these never really develop much or are forgotten once they start fawning over the main character...which they all do of course. Sadly very little is done with the characters from the normal world that are introduced.

This is a fan-service" VN designed to titillate male players
date: and there is nothing wrong with that and the game does this well. however there is very little on offer for anyone else The artwork and backgrounds are good although lacking variety and the occasional CG image of a scene (usually of the girls in "fan-service" poses) are all very well drawn. The music is ok
recommended: a few tracks repeated for different types of scenes but non of them are particularly unpleasant...the real downside is that there doesn’t seem to be any voice work.\n\nIt took about two and a half hours to finish
hoursPlayed: that includes going back and seeing the festival with both groups
voteText: there isn't really any replayablitiy (my total playtime includes the time for mining trading cards). At full price this is a difficult product to recommend however if it's on sale
